narrow.translation[0].definitions[0].def: measuring only a small distance from one side to the other, especially in relation to the length
narrow.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: a long, narrow band of cloud
the narrow passage between the cottage and the house
narrow.translation[0].definitions[1].def: a narrow attitude or way of looking at a situation is too limited and does not consider enough possibilities
narrow.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: You’ve got a very narrow view of life.
Some teachers have a narrow vision of what art is.
narrow.translation[0].definitions[2].def: limited in range or number of things
narrow.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: The company offered only a narrow range of financial services.
narrow.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to make something narrower, or to become narrower
narrow.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: He narrowed his eyes and gazed at the horizon.
The track divided into two and narrowed.
narrow.translation[1].definitions[1].def: if a range, difference etc narrows, or if something narrows it, it becomes less
narrow.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: The choice of goods available is narrowing.
The economic gap between the two halves of the country was beginning to narrow.
narrow.translation[2].definitions[0].exa: The polls give Mr. Edwards a narrow lead.
Analysts had expected a narrow decline in pretax earnings.
The Senate rejected the bid by a narrow margin (=it was almost accepted).
narrow.translation[2].definitions[1].def: including only a small number of parts or things
narrow.translation[2].definitions[1].exa: firms that make a narrow range of goods
the country’s weak and narrow economic base
narrow.translation[2].definitions[2].def: if shares, currencies etc trade in a narrow range, their price does not go up or down very much
narrow.translation[2].definitions[2].exa: The dollar had been trading in a narrow range against the yen.
narrow.translation[2].definitions[3].def: a narrow market is one in which the buying or selling of shares has a great effect on their price, for example because there are only a small number of them available
narrow.translation[2].definitions[3].exa: Cobalt is traded in a narrow market which means speculators can drive prices up or down rapidly.
narrow.translation[3].definitions[0].def: to become less or to make something less in range, difference etc
narrow.translation[3].definitions[0].exa: Growing competition for contracts will narrow profit margins.
The gap between the two companies is clearly narrowing.
The choice was quickly narrowed down to Luxembourg or Dublin.
